paragraphs.content: The attitude for experimentation and artistic research has led me from the very beginning to explore diverse, unconventional musical styles. Improvisation, interplay, blends of electronic and acoustic sounds, polyrhythmic explorations, and interdisciplinary glimpses into nature, mathematics and music are defining feature of my work.

Born in Alessandria into a family of musicians, I first approached the violin and later transitioned to electric bass and double bass. I studied jazz at the Conservatories of Alessandria, Piacenza and Rome. Additionally, I earned a degree in Biological Sciences (Ecology) at the Università del Piemonte Orientale. These studies form the foundation upon which my artistic research journey began, leading me in 2022 to win a scholarship for the second-level AReMus Master's at the Santa Cecilia Conservatory in Rome and, in 2023, to be selected for a doctoral program in artistic research at Roma Tre University/Santa Cecilia Conservatory.

My current research projects focus on the interrelations between improvisation and cultural/environmental ecology, materializing in post-human, site-specific improvisational performances where hybrids of environmental and performative sounds emerge.
Leonardo Barbierato, «[in situ] : re-thinking the role of musical improvisation performance in the context of the ecological and cultural crisis», RUUKKU - Studiesin Artistic Research, Vol 21, 2024
Leonardo Barbierato, «Listening as improvisation, listening as artivism: site-specific inter-actions during [in situ] performance», simm-posium 9, 2024

project_card_insita.title: patterns for transcendence // [insita]
project_card_insita.content: Patterns for Transcendence is the project in which I pursue an artistic exploration of the interrelationships between improvisation and environmental/cultural context.[insita], the first recorded work, materializes as a fusion of photographic and musical imagery, blending electronic and acoustic sounds, seeking a balance between composition, rationality, spontaneity, and instinctiveness,reflecting on the immanence and human-ecological transcendence. Patterns for Transcendence is an audio-visual project in which eight photographs, containing urban and natural elements, serve as the starting point from which sounds emerge, transforming images, patterns and abstractions into suggestions for as many musical compositions, blending synthetic-electronic and acoustic sonic elements. Images born from places (and non-places) in different contexts, at various latitudes, give life to eight original compositions, ranging from free improvisation to electronics, from noise to jazz.                      Line-up:                             Leonardo Barbierato: electric bass     Attilio Sepe: alto saxophone           Gianpiero Malfatto: trombone           Lorenzo Morra: piano/synthesizer       Riccardo Marchese: drums

project_card_insitu.title: patterns for transcendence // [in situ]
project_card_insitu.content: Patterns for Transcendence is the project in which I pursues an artistic exploration of the interrelationships between improvisation and environmental/cultural context. [in situ] is a site-specific improvisation performances in pristine or degraded ecosystems. This project stems from the need to explore the space between social ecology, post-human environmentalism and improvisation. The ecosystem in which the improvisation takes place, with its human, other-than-human, living and non-living elements is a fundamental aspect of the improvisation in [in situ], making each performance a unique and unrepeatable event, a complex system linked to the place, the audience, myself, and the time. The fundamental idea of [in situ] is a collective, brieftopic, ecotonal improvisation in which all the elements, human or other-than-human, are free to participate and be considered ‘performative’.

project_card_slwjm.title: SLWJM
project_card_slwjm.content: Born out of the common need to create a sound deeply rooted in black music and combine it with electronic experimentation, free improvisation, and progressive elements. Following the release of the EP Undone I, which was aired on several national radio stations such as M2O and Radio 24, an intense promotional live activity ensued, seeing them perform on numerous prestigious stages (including Legend Club in Milan and Torino Jazz Club) and festivals like Neon Noon and Torino Jazz Festival, with the show Black Hi(T)story Revisited alongside Federico Sacchi, which sold out. The single "Nothin' but U," released in May 2020, and the cover "Fiori rosa, fiori di pesco," released in July 2020, anticipate the album MEGA, which was released in January 2021. On August 24, 2020, they received the first prize for best emerging band at the Aim Festival contest at the Sforzesco Castle in Milan.
